commit_message:
Updates package api-ref.

This patch makes the following changes to the package api-ref:
  - Adds an package overview
  - Removes 500 error codes (any endpoint can arguably throw a 500
    but a 500 is not an expected error code)
  - Adds missing X-Openstack-Request-Id from response parameters
    for consistency
  - Adds additional status codes that can be returned by endpoints
  - Updates deprecated response bodies

Change-Id: I2f103c2a67a4831d7ad0c47ce142a3a82accc0ba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/60/460760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: In Murano, each application, as well as the form of application data entry, is defined by packages. Package Structure ================= The structure of the Murano application package is predefined. An application could be successfully uploaded to an application catalog. The application package root folder should contain the following: * ``manifest.yaml`` file is the application entry point. .. note:: The filename is fixed, so do not use any custom names. * ``Classes`` folder contains MuranoPL class definitions. * ``Resources`` folder contaisn execution plan templates as well as the ``scripts`` folder with all the files required for an application deployment located inside it. * ``UI`` folder contains the dynamic UI YAML definitions. * ``logo.png`` file (optional) is an image file associated with your application. The logo appears in the Application Catalog within Murano Dasboard. .. note:: There are no special limitations regarding an image filename. However, if it differs from the default ``logo.png``, specify it in an application manifest file. * ``images.lst`` file (optional) contains a list of images required by an application. .. note:: A bundle is a collection of packages. In the Community App Catalog, you can find such bundles as ``container-based-apps``, ``app-servers``, and so on. The packages in the Application Catalog are sorted by usage. - 403Upload a package to the application catalog. - 403 - 403 - 401 - 403Retrieve UI definition for an application. - 403 - 404Returns the entire UI definition for the package, if the logo has a UI definition. Below is an example of a very basic UI definition:: Version: 2.2 Forms: - appConfiguration: fields: - name: license type: string description: Apache License, Version 2.0 hidden: false required: false - 403 - 404Returns the binary logo data for the package, if the package has a logo.
deleted_lines: - 500 - X-Openstack-Request-Id: request_idCreate a package. - X-Openstack-Request-Id: request_id - 500 - X-Openstack-Request-Id: request_id - 500 - X-Openstack-Request-Id: request_id - 500 - 500Retrieve UI definition for a application. - 500This request does not return anything in the response body. :language: javascript - 500This request does not return anything in the response body. :language: javascript

commit_message:
Fix race condition for primary component bootstrap

Create node is_pc flag before starting to check if there
is more than one of those flags. Thus, we avoid race condition
when there is 0 is_pc flags and galera starts with --wsrep-new-cluster
on 2 nodes.

We set it before the check and, as setting them is synchronous through
Pacemaker CIB, in that case when >1 nodes attempt to bootstrap with
--wsrep-new-cluster, only one node will see <= 1 is_pc flags. Others
will see more than one and fail and reattempt to start. At that point
one of the nodes will already be bootstrapped, thus reelection will not
be triggered and the section of bootstrap will be skipped

Change-Id: I82a71132eef7877ac7ab1ed04263044b3b1e8d9b
Closes-bug: #1617400
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
xiv: enable get fc targets by host

There are cases where the driver need to list  only the FC targets
which are accessible to a  specific host

Change-Id: Iaafce09e056acb0f1eb5b5bdc124dd12207ad287
Closes-Bug: #1687289
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/77/461277/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: fc_port_list = self._call_xiv_xcli("fc_port_list") if host is None: target_wwpns += ( [t.get('wwpn') for t in fc_port_list if t.get('wwpn') != '0000000000000000' and t.get('role') == 'Target' and t.get('port_state') == 'Online']) else: host_conect_list = self._call_xiv_xcli("host_connectivity_list", host=host.get('name')) for connection in host_conect_list: fc_port = connection.get('local_fc_port') target_wwpns += ( [t.get('wwpn') for t in fc_port_list if t.get('wwpn') != '0000000000000000' and t.get('role') == 'Target' and t.get('port_state') == 'Online' and t.get('component_id') == fc_port])
deleted_lines: target_wwpns += ( [t.get('wwpn') for t in self._call_xiv_xcli("fc_port_list") if t.get('wwpn') != '0000000000000000' and t.get('role') == 'Target' and t.get('port_state') == 'Online'])

subject: IPv6 VIP addresses need to be /128
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-26 09:45:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo/commit/14e07c799ca2843e219b93a6a46b78ac1c51cb1d', 'message': 'WIP IPv6 VIP addresses need to be /128

We currently hardcode /64 as our VIP addresses when using IPv6.
The problem with this is that some server code might bind to that
IP as a source address when doing inter-cluster communication
(rabbitmq/galera for example). So when the VIP moves there will
be effectively a network outage between the nodes, which should not
happen.

Likely this was hardcoded to /64 because the RA IPaddr2 needs a nic
parameter when /128 is specified. This is due to:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1445628

WIP: Because we are still working on the upgrade path and also need to
test this.

Partial-Bug: #1686357

commit_message:
IPv6 VIP addresses need to be /128

We currently hardcode /64 as our VIP addresses when using IPv6.
The problem with this is that some server code might bind to that
IP as a source address when doing inter-cluster communication
(rabbitmq/galera for example). So when the VIP moves there will
be effectively a network outage between the nodes, which should not
happen.

Likely this was hardcoded to /64 because the RA IPaddr2 needs a nic
parameter when /128 is specified. This is due to:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1445628

We also make sure we use the ipv6_addrlabel option set to 99 so that
they will never be used as source ip addresses.

Depends-On: I7fcf15a00aedbdcfb21db501ad46c69fb97ec30c
Partial-Bug: #1686357

Change-Id: Ibefde870512ad1e03ff12f7aea91b3734f03f96f
Co-Authored-By: Sofer Athlan-Guyot <sathlang@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marios Andreou <mandreou@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/28/460028/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NB: Until the IPaddr2 RA has a fix for https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1445628 # we need to specify the nic when creating the ipv6 vip. if is_ipv6_address($ip_address) { $netmask = '128' $nic = interface_for_ip($ip_address) $nic = '' nic => $nic,

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-04-20 16:51:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/murano/commit/00da2593160bcaf6a761013de7939950af454b45', 'message': 'Allow users to assign a security group to an app

This patch allows users to supply a list* of their own security groups to
an instance, rather than using the application defined one (build via
the SecurityGroupManager).

* Note, while we can support multiple security groups, murano-dashboard
currently has no UI element to select multiple items. This means that
currently users are restricted to selecting one group. If/when this the
UI is improved this change can easily support multiple groups.

Example
=======

Application authors can make this available in their apps as follows:

UI.yaml
-------
Forms:
  - instanceConfiguration:
      fields:
          ...
        - name: securityGroups
          type: securitygroup
          label: Security Group
          required: false

Class.yaml:
----------
  Application:
    ?:
       type: com.paul.HelloWorld
    instance:
      ?:
        type: io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance
      name: $.instanceConfiguration.hostname
      securityGroups: $.instanceConfiguration.securityGroups
      ...

DocImpact
Change-Id: I60d37cfe034c467e894ee93cf3718e463bf49337
Partially-Implements: blueprint app-use-existing-security-group

commit_message:
Allow users to assign a security group to an app

This patch allows users to supply a list* of their own security groups to
an instance, rather than using the application defined one (built via
the SecurityGroupManager).

* Note, while we can support multiple security groups, murano-dashboard
currently has no UI element to select multiple items. This means that
currently users are restricted to selecting one group. If/when the
UI is improved this change can easily support multiple groups.

Example
=======

Application authors can make this available in their apps as follows:

UI.yaml
-------
Forms:
  - instanceConfiguration:
      fields:
          ...
        - name: securityGroups
          type: securitygroup
          label: Security Group
          required: false

Class.yaml:
----------
  Application:
    ?:
       type: com.paul.HelloWorld
    instance:
      ?:
        type: io.murano.resources.LinuxMuranoInstance
      name: $.instanceConfiguration.hostname
      securityGroups: $.instanceConfiguration.securityGroups
      ...

DocImpact
Change-Id: I60d37cfe034c467e894ee93cf3718e463bf49337
Partially-Implements: blueprint app-use-existing-security-group

added_lines: HELM_VERSION=v2.3.0 TMP_DIR=$(mktemp -d) KUBE_VERSION=v1.6.0 KUBECONFIG=${HOME}/.kubeadm-aio/admin.conf export KUBEADM_IMAGE=openstack-helm/kubeadm-aio:v1.6 DOCKER_KUBEADM_PATH=~/openstack-helm/tools/kubeadm-aio function pre_aio_docker { sudo apt-get update -y sudo apt-get install -y \ docker.io \ nfs-common \ git \ make } function pre_kubeadm_aio { # install kubectl curl -sSL https://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-release/release/${KUBE_VERSION}/bin/linux/amd64/kubectl -o ${TMP_DIR}/kubectl chmod +x ${TMP_DIR}/kubectl sudo mv ${TMP_DIR}/kubectl /usr/local/bin/kubectl # install helm curl -sSL https://storage.googleapis.com/kubernetes-helm/helm-${HELM_VERSION}-linux-amd64.tar.gz | tar -zxv --strip-components=1 -C ${TMP_DIR} sudo mv ${TMP_DIR}/helm /usr/local/bin/helm rm -rf ${TMP_DIR} } function get_osh_repo { git clone https://git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-helm } function kubeadm_aio { sudo docker build --pull -t ${KUBEADM_IMAGE} ${DOCKER_KUBEADM_PATH} } function kube_config { ~/openstack-helm/tools/kubeadm-aio/kubeadm-aio-launcher.sh mkdir -p ${HOME}/.kube cat ${HOME}/.kubeadm-aio/admin.conf > ${HOME}/.kube/config } function docker_logs { sudo docker logs kubeadm-aio } function dummy_network { sudo docker exec kubelet /usr/bin/openstack-helm-aio-network-prep } function helm_lint { helm init helm serve& helm repo add local http://localhost:8879/charts make -C ~/openstack-helm/ } pre_aio_docker pre_kubeadm_aio get_osh_repo kubeadm_aio kube_config dummy_network #docker_logs exit 0

commit_message:
Dump ARP entry for the failed ip address on connectivity failure

If a test fails with connectivity issue when pinging a VM, it's
sometimes hard to say if that's a legic OpenStack bug, or the physical
infrastructure is messed (like floating IP pools are incorrectly shared
across multiple installations, making them struggle for place in ARP
tables of others).

The patch logs the ARP entry for the failed address if present on the
tempest node. Nothing is logged if the node doesn't have the entry
(which is probably the case for most use cases where the tester node
accesses controllers through a router).

Change-Id: I10cbd933e14f37392f149b794d3201d9ece20304
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/92/454892/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def dump_arptable(self): cmd = ['arp', '-nv'] proc = subprocess.Popen(cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE) stdout, _ = proc.communicate() LOG.debug('ARP table:\n%s', stdout) result = self.ping_ip_address(ip_address, should_succeed=should_connect, mtu=mtu) if not result or True: # dump some more information about the node running tempest that # may help to understand if that's network setup issue, or indeed # openstack connectivity problem. self.dump_arptable() self.fail(msg)

commit_message:
Creates config options for policy.json paths

Removes unsused "path" parameter from rbac_policy_parser.py.
Allows for configuration of policy.json paths by service for
Cinder, Glance, Keystone, Neutron, and Nova.

commit_message:
Move tests from volumes into volumes actions.

This patch moves the tests for the following policy actions:

  - volume_extension:volume_admin_actions:reset_status
  - volume_extension:volume_admin_actions:force_delete

into test_volume_actions_rbac because they do not belong
in test_volumes_rbac, as resetting a status of a volume [0]
and force-deleting a volume [1] are a part of the volume
actions API, not the volumes API.

As there are no tests left in test_volumes_rbac after relocating
these 2 tests, the file is deleted.

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html?expanded=reset-a-volume-s-statuses-detail
[1] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/api/volume/admin/test_volumes_actions.py

Change-Id: Idc0286de76e1a58826f411de60988975694a2da3

commit_message:
Handle journald timestamps with microseconds

Our existing timestamp parsing rules could handle syslog format
timestamps with seconds but not microseconds. Journald output is giving
us microseconds so be sure to parse those too.

Change-Id: I44165b4744495ce825bc3b3b2cd908df004c5325

monasca-persister: Rotate logs

Add config for logrotate. Otherwise the disk might run out of space.

commit_message:
Add support for file-backed ephemeral disk

Adds support for file-backed ephemeral disk as a localdisk replacement
for lvm.
Supports both RAW and QCOW2 files. Resizing a QCOW2 based instance is
not supported.

Change-Id: I63b28b03b9846d55cd72772794975f429a68d74a
Implements: bp file-io-driver

commit_message:
devref and reno for nova-{api,metadata}-wsgi scripts

This provides a brief explanation of the new nova-api-wsgi [1] and
nova-metadata-wsgi [2] scripts in the Architecture section of the devref
with links to the new doc added to the man pages for the eventlet
scripts.

The nova-api.rst mentioned ec2 so figured best to fix that now
rather than forget about it, despite not being entirely germane.

There is also a reno note that indicates the availability of the new
scripts.

There is a devstack change which is testing the new wsgi scripts as
well as forcing grenade to not use them at
If2d7e363a6541854f2e30c03171bef7a41aff745

[1] I7c4acfaa6c50ac0e4d6de69eb62ec5bbad72ff85
[2] Icb35fe2b94ab02c0ba8ba8129ae18aae0f794756

Change-Id: I351b2af3b256d3031bd2a65feba0495e815f8427
Related-Bug: #1661360

commit_message:
Add specs and validation jobs for service-types-authority

There is a patch to service-types-authority to add docs publication and
validation checks. Add jobs to support that. We should wait until the
service-types-authority change has at least some amount of approval, but
that change depends-on this one, so the change itself should be self
gating.

Change-Id: I5eb1503f815440cac2d127c1f1fec1318e894323
Needed-by: I0f5023d28d9344e87db5a01e7fd1f19a427bec4c

commit_message:
Fix keystone.tests.unit.test_v3_oauth1.MaliciousOAuth1Tests

Config options 'access_token_duration' and 'request_token_duration' only
allow value >= 0, so override with value 1 and use freezegun to wait
token to be expired. This commit also enhance condition check for these
two options.

Partial-Bug: #1686921
Change-Id: I65306b9fc5eec6b8146ba5130f7d6e6cb229810e

Collect lvmdump info in logs

We have been having problems with lvm and cinder recently. Record the
state of lvm to aid in debugging these issues.

Related-Bug: 1687044

commit_message:
Use plain routes list for os-floating-ip-pools endpoint instead of stevedore

This patch adds os-floating-ip-pools related routes by a plain list, instead
of using stevedore. After all the Nova API endpoints moves to
the plain routes list, the usage of stevedore for API loading will be
removed from Nova.

Partial-implement-blueprint api-no-more-extensions-pike

Change-Id: I50de6ca3fa7ad6bd1ca317682fd0ab0362ea9e29

The run_process function in devstack is intended for things that

commit_message:
don't use run_process for odl

The run_process function in devstack is intended for things that
aren't already daemonizing properly, that have some foreground to work
with, potentially putting output onto the console. It was not intended
for services that already have init systems.

Don't use it for odl. It has a start/stop system already, which is
sufficient.

Change-Id: I0ad88d3ab0eb11c17f9b1140a2e4318990c946a8
(cherry picked from commit d615c9cd74055ea35ef889c47006b7af83be5382)

commit_message:
Log exception when journal entry processing fails

If an entry processing fails unexpectedly then this is a bug and we
should get the entire exception info in the log to debug it.

Besides, the message field of BaseException is deprecated since Python
2.6 and removed in Python 3 so we shouldn't use it.

Change-Id: I66af810e0b8d51f8f4d6e6e3a6a72b9bde26e2cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/55/449055/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: except exceptions.ConnectionError: except Exception: LOG.error(_LE("Error while processing %(op)s %(type)s %(id)s"), log_dict, exc_info=True)
deleted_lines: except exceptions.ConnectionError as e: except Exception as e: log_dict['error'] = e.message LOG.error(_LE("Error while processing %(op)s %(type)s %(id)s;" " Error: %(error)s"), log_dict)

commit_message:
Don't call journal's run_sync_thread in unit tests

This method takes care of the general journal processing loop using
events and notifications, there's no need or reason to call it from
various unit tests that want the journal to process the entries, instead
the unit tests will now call sync_pending_entries which just processes
the pending entries.

BGPVPN tests had to be fixed not to use mock values in their fake data.
This causes dumpjson to freak out, but that was swallowed by the
exception handler in sync_pending_entries.
However, that exception handling is referencing e.message which is
deprecated and doesn't exist in Python 3 so it cause a ValueError which
used to be swallowed by run_sync_thread but since we're not calling it
any more it actually propagated to the tests and caused them to fail
(the py35 ones).

Change-Id: I2846345e31fe7c6d964bc946c7da48ab64f1ec61
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/10/448110/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.thread.sync_pending_entries(exit_after_run=True)

commit_message:
Handle the new journald based logs

These logs have slightly more information. Also they have syslog
timestamps not iso8601 timestamps.

Change-Id: I7eaa35b3259d17f7e1f5f69e5acf41bddec685f7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/logstash-filters refs/changes/38/462238/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: pattern => "^(%{TIMESTAMP_ISO8601}|%{SYSLOGTIMESTAMP}) " pattern => "^(%{TIMESTAMP_ISO8601}|%{SYSLOGTIMESTAMP})%{SPACE}%{NUMBER}%{SPACE}(TRACE|ERROR)" match => { "message" => "(?m)^(%{TIMESTAMP_ISO8601:logdate}|%{SYSLOGTIMESTAMP:logdate})%{SPACE}(%{DATA:syslog_program}(?:\[%{POSINT:syslog_pid}\])?:|%{NUMBER:pid})?%{SPACE}?(?<loglevel>AUDIT|CRITICAL|DEBUG|INFO|TRACE|WARNING|ERROR) \[?\b%{NOTSPACE:module}\b\]?%{SPACE}?%{GREEDYDATA:logmessage}?" }

commit_message:
[Fix gate] Fix failing identity v2 admin tests

This patch fixes the failing identity tests that
belong to the v2 admin API [0].

Due to recent changes to Keystone and DevStack,
the v2 admin API tests fail if run outright.

Tempest now skips the v2 admin tests uness
``CONF.identity_feature_enabled.api_v2_admin`` is true [1];
Patrole should do the same.

This patch makes the following changes:
  - Skips identity v2 admin tests unless
    ``CONF.identity_feature_enabled.api_v2_admin`` is true
  - Removes superfluous tempest.conf overrides from
    post_test_hook
  - Updates ``rbac_utils.switch_role`` to ensure that admin
    identity credentials are properly configured and that
    the ``roles_v3_client`` is always used
  - Refactors test_projects_rbac in v2 identity because
    the API belongs to both the admin and non-admin API,
    which was causing OverPermission error to be thrown.

[0] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v2-admin/
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/458844/

Change-Id: Ic698d0b2cf669793aaad6aff972ba155ef993e4a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/37/461837/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not test_obj.auth_provider.credentials.is_admin_available( identity_version=self.identity_version): msg = "Missing Identity Admin API credentials in configuration." raise cls.RbacResourceSetupFailed(msg) self.roles_client = test_obj.os_admin.roles_v3_client
deleted_lines: if self.identity_version.endswith('v3'): self.roles_client = test_obj.os_admin.roles_v3_client else: self.roles_client = test_obj.os_admin.roles_client

Change-Id: Ia04058232a839c4eaf2c85849e8b71879ae414e7
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly set 'builders' option

An upcoming release of pbr will require explicitly stating which
builders are requested, rather than defaulting to html and man. Head off
any potential impact this may cause by explicitly setting this
configuration now.

'ansible_become' through an inventory variable.

This feature is implemented for Pike already in
I75bd18b3a1875daa5639dd141fb7bbd6e1c54118

is also removed from specs because it was already
changed and deprecated in Ocata and is removed in Pike.

subject: don't use run_process for odl
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-03 01:50:57.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/entry_points'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/0659533fa11de4e0314fb744a346411ec46fb455', 'message': "don't use run_process for odl

The run_process function in devstack is intended for things that
aren't already daemonizing properly, that have some foreground to work
with, potentially putting output onto the console. It was not intended
for services that already have init systems.

Don't use it for odl. It has a start/stop system already, which is
sufficient.

Change-Id: I0ad88d3ab0eb11c17f9b1140a2e4318990c946a8
(cherry picked from commit d615c9cd74055ea35ef889c47006b7af83be5382)
"}]
commit_message:
don't use run_process for odl

The run_process function in devstack is intended for things that
aren't already daemonizing properly, that have some foreground to work
with, potentially putting output onto the console. It was not intended
for services that already have init systems.

Don't use it for odl. It has a start/stop system already, which is
sufficient.

Change-Id: I0ad88d3ab0eb11c17f9b1140a2e4318990c946a8
(cherry picked from commit d615c9cd74055ea35ef889c47006b7af83be5382)

Change-Id: Ia56d7344572a0addfd4fd5c93832dc66f630e93d

commit_message:
Ensure that all repos are configured properly

It appears that yum-config-manager does not properly
configure all the repositories reliably when trying
to give it a bunch of them to do at once.

This patch sets each repo to be enabled and have the
priority set one at a time.

Change-Id: Ia56d7344572a0addfd4fd5c93832dc66f630e93d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-pip_install refs/changes/68/462168/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Enable and set repo priorities command: | --enable {{ item.name }} --setopt="{{ item.name }}.priority={{ item.priority }}" with_items: - name: base priority: 50 - name: epel priority: 99 - name: extras priority: 50 - name: openstack-ocata priority: 50 - name: rdo-qemu-ev priority: 50 - name: updates priority: 50 tags: - openstack-yum-packages - openstack-packages
deleted_lines: - name: Increase priority of all repos to 50 except EPEL command: > --enable openstack-ocata --setopt="openstack-ocata.priority=50" --enable rdo-qemu-ev --setopt="rdo-qemu-ev.priority=50" --enable base --setopt="base.priority=50" --enable updates --setopt="updates.priority=50" --enable extras --setopt="extras.priority=50" --enable epel

commit_message:
Move 'external-network-exists' validator to 'openstack/validators.py'

Change-Id: Ieaea40a9df60d9b0b2997dd5dc9c077e81c12b20
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/25/458525/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2017: Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import ddt import mock from glanceclient import exc as glance_exc from novaclient import exceptions as nova_exc from rally import exceptions from rally.plugins.openstack import validators from tests.unit import test credentials = { "openstack": { "admin": mock.Mock(), } } config = {"args": {"image": {"id": "fake_id", "min_ram": 10, "size": 1024 ** 3, "min_disk": 10.0 * (1024 ** 3), "image_name": "foo_image"}, "flavor": {"id": "fake_flavor_id", "name": "test"}, "foo_image": {"id": "fake_image_id"} }, "context": {"images": {"image_name": "foo_image"} } } @ddt.ddt class ExternalNetworkExistsValidatorTestCase(test.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(ExternalNetworkExistsValidatorTestCase, self).setUp() self.validator = validators.ExternalNetworkExistsValidator("net") self.config = config self.credentials = credentials @ddt.unpack @ddt.data( {"foo_conf": {}}, {"foo_conf": {"args": {"net": "custom"}}}, {"foo_conf": {"args": {"net": "non_exist"}}, "err_msg": "External (floating) network with name non_exist " "not found. Available networks: ['public', 'custom']"}, {"foo_conf": {"args": {"name": "custom"}}, "net1_name": {"net": "public"}, "net2_name": {"net": "custom"}} ) def test_validator(self, foo_conf, net1_name="public", net2_name="custom", err_msg=""): admin_creds = self.credentials["openstack"]["admin"] clients = admin_creds.clients.return_value net1 = mock.MagicMock() net2 = mock.MagicMock() clients.nova().floating_ip_pools.list.return_value = [net1, net2] net1.name = net1_name net2.name = net2_name result = self.validator.validate(foo_conf, self.credentials, None, None) if err_msg: self.assertIsInstance(result, validators.ValidationResult) self.assertEqual(err_msg, result.msg) elif result: self.assertIsNone(result, "Unexpected result '%s'" % result.msg) else: self.assertIsNone(result)

added_lines: settings_utils.update_local_settings(__name__)# Ensure SECRET_KEY ensure_local_path(__name__) ensure_secret_key(__name__)settings_utils.update_dashboards(__name__)settings_utils.show_warnings(__name__)
deleted_lines: # allow to drop settings snippets into a local_settings_dir LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH = os.path.join(ROOT_PATH, "local", "local_settings.d") if os.path.exists(LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH): for (dirpath, dirnames, filenames) in os.walk(LOCAL_SETTINGS_DIR_PATH): for filename in sorted(filenames): if filename.endswith(".py"): try: with open(os.path.join(dirpath, filename)) as f: exec(f.read()) except Exception as e: logging.exception( "Can not exec settings snippet %s", filename)# Ensure that we always have a SECRET_KEY set, even when no local_settings.py # file is present. See local_settings.py.example for full documentation on the # horizon.utils.secret_key module and its use. if not SECRET_KEY: if not LOCAL_PATH: LOCAL_PATH = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)), 'local') from horizon.utils import secret_key SECRET_KEY = secret_key.generate_or_read_from_file(os.path.join(LOCAL_PATH, '.secret_key_store'))# Load the pluggable dashboard settings import openstack_dashboard.enabled import openstack_dashboard.local.enabled INSTALLED_APPS = list(INSTALLED_APPS) # Make sure it's mutable settings_utils.update_dashboards( [ openstack_dashboard.enabled, openstack_dashboard.local.enabled, ], HORIZON_CONFIG, INSTALLED_APPS, ) # Here comes the Django settings deprecation section. Being at the very end # of settings.py allows it to catch the settings defined in local_settings.py # or inside one of local_settings.d/ snippets. if 'HORIZON_IMAGES_ALLOW_UPLOAD' in globals(): message = 'The setting HORIZON_IMAGES_ALLOW_UPLOAD is deprecated in ' \ 'Newton and will be removed in P release. Use the setting ' \ 'HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE instead.' if not HORIZON_IMAGES_ALLOW_UPLOAD: message += ' Keep in mind that HORIZON_IMAGES_ALLOW_UPLOAD set to ' \ 'False overrides the value of HORIZON_IMAGES_UPLOAD_MODE.' logging.warning(message)

It appears that yum-config-manager does not properly
configure all the repositories reliably when trying
to give it a bunch of them to do at once.

This patch sets each repo to be enabled and have the
priority set one at a time.

Change-Id: I8ef12ba1f397993376c8d89cfa9a65ebad978b8b
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-05-03 15:27:46.000000000', 'files': ['vars/redhat-7.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts/commit/a75301a8931f2e05fea984c89fc363fadc6f2012', 'message': "Remove EPEL/RDO package installs from cache prep

The keys and yum.repos.d files are copied from the host
and imported prior to the current download/install/config
steps. The distro packages are all installed before this
too, proving that they're already working prior to these
steps.

Obviously these extra commands are not necessary, so they
may as well be removed.

Change-Id: I8ef12ba1f397993376c8d89cfa9a65ebad978b8b
"}]
commit_message:
Remove EPEL/RDO package installs from cache prep

The keys and yum.repos.d files are copied from the host
and imported prior to the current download/install/config
steps. The distro packages are all installed before this
too, proving that they're already working prior to these
steps.

Obviously these extra commands are not necessary, so they
may as well be removed.

Change-Id: I8ef12ba1f397993376c8d89cfa9a65ebad978b8b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts refs/changes/79/462179/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: yum-config-manager --enable base --setopt="base.priority=50" yum-config-manager --enable epel --setopt="epel.priority=99" yum-config-manager --enable extras --setopt="extras.priority=50" yum-config-manager --enable openstack-ocata --setopt="openstack-ocata.priority=50" yum-config-manager --enable rdo-qemu-ev --setopt="rdo-qemu-ev.priority=50" yum-config-manager --enable updates --setopt="updates.priority=50"
deleted_lines: yum-config-manager --enable openstack-ocata --setopt="openstack-ocata.priority=50" --enable rdo-qemu-ev --setopt="rdo-qemu-ev.priority=50" \ --enable base --setopt="base.priority=50" --enable updates --setopt="updates.priority=50" --enable extras --setopt="extras.priority=50" \ --enable epel

commit_message:
Fix test_minimum_password_age_and_password_expires_days_deactivated

The [security_compliance]password_expires_days option allows minimum
value 1, it's default value None means the feature is disabled,
so don't need override its value in test.

Partial-Bug: #1686921
Change-Id: I288f1a2437f26d8cc06803482d03cbb9042df189

commit_message:
Fix keystone.tests.unit.test_backend_ldap.LDAPIdentity

* Config option [ldap]/alias_dereferencing only allows value in
  [never, searching, always, finding, default], oslo.config will
  ensure that, so don't need test the case.

* Config option [ldap]/query_scope only allows value in [one, sub],
  oslo.config will ensure that, so don't need test the case.

Partial-Bug: #1686921

Change-Id: Ie262acd0386318ff5f818f8688bdbb40f4939360

commit_message:
operation_log: Honor settings parameters

Previously 'format' and 'mask_fields' in OPERATION_LOG_OPTIONS
were completely ignored. OPERATION_LOG_OPTIONS is a dict, but
the logic tried to get attributes, so these options were ignored.

Change-Id: Ide4826ebf74218873a81b67aaa0dd817c4798702
Closes-Bug: #1675176
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/98/448798/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.mask_fields = _log_option.get("mask_fields", ['password']) self.format = _log_option.get("format", _default_format)

commit_message:
Remove test_metadata_invalid_contact_type

oslo.config will ensure option [saml]/idp_contact_type with parameter
choices only allow values in ('technical', 'support', 'administrative',
'billing', 'other') in runtime, so don't need test in KeyStone.
This commit also remove check code for the option.

Partial-Bug: #1686921
Related-Bug: #1517839

Change-Id: I0c78a25a353d04dbe46e9679771c51b22b677a27

commit_message:
Set NOVA_USE_MOD_WSGI False for target

This ensure that for Pike we will not use the new uwsgi
functionality for the nova-api anod nova-metadata services, ensuring
that we continue to use the default infrastructure over the
release transition. This can be removed when both cycles are using
uwsgi.

Change-Id: I7b22692ea9135547d93b08724f1f9ef060f13007
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/grenade refs/changes/43/460543/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Don't let Nova use WSGI devstack_localrc target "NOVA_USE_MOD_WSGI=False"

commit_message:
Fix test keystone.tests.unit.test_token_bind.BindTest

[token] enforce_token_bind option was deprecated for removal, and
the 'bind' option doesn't enforce a set of choices. I think the better
option here would be to remove the choices field and let the backend
enforce correctness.

Partial-Bug: #1686921
Change-Id: If0a537237a477303c0ce84945d83ce440f4d7812
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/75/461275/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use cryptography instead of pycrypto

pycrypto is no longer maintained [1]. This patch rewrites functions
using pycrypto and replaces them with the cryptography equivalent

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113568.html

Change-Id: I438fdbb76ceb7edf23bc5640596ed64feb59aa46
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/18/452318/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import padding from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import rsa from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import algorithms from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import Cipher from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import modesfrom os import urandom self._bs = 16 self._salt = urandom(self._bs - len(self.SALT_MAGIC)) cipher = Cipher( algorithms.AES(self._key), modes.CBC(self._iv), backend = default_backend() ) encryptor = cipher.encryptor() ciphertext = encryptor.update(text) + encryptor.finalize() def _random_AES_passphrase(self, length): key = rsa.generate_private_key( key_size = modulus, public_exponent = passphrase, backend = default_backend() ) public_key = key.public_key() ciphertext = public_key.encrypt( text, padding.PKCS1v15( mgf = padding.PKCS1v15(algorithm = hashes.SHA1()), algorithm = hashes.SHA1() ) ) random_passphrase = self._random_AES_passphrase(501)
deleted_lines: from Crypto.Cipher import AES from Crypto.Cipher import PKCS1_v1_5 from Crypto.PublicKey import RSA from Crypto import Random self._bs = AES.block_size self._salt = Random.new().read(self._bs - len(self.SALT_MAGIC)) cipher = AES.new(self._key, AES.MODE_CBC, self._iv) ciphertext = cipher.encrypt(self._pad(text)) def _random_AES_passpharse(self, length): key = RSA.construct((modulus, passphrase)) cipher = PKCS1_v1_5.new(key) ciphertext = cipher.encrypt(text) random_passphrase = self._random_AES_passpharse(501)

commit_message:
Fix a typo in ipv6 addrlabel

In Ifd42683efae2cb29be3fcc1d5afdb62dad1bd82d in my last revision I
slipped in a typo. This needs to be fixed before we default to use addr
labels on ipv6.

As a reference the two parameters for addr labels are called:
- lvs_ipv6_addrlabel (boolen)
  https://github.com/ClusterLabs/resource-agents/blob/master/heartbeat/IPaddr2#L232
- lvs_ipv6_addrlabel_value (integer)
  https://github.com/ClusterLabs/resource-agents/blob/master/heartbeat/IPaddr2#L243

Change-Id: I7fcf15a00aedbdcfb21db501ad46c69fb97ec30c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-pacemaker refs/changes/73/462073/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: default => " lvs_ipv6_addrlabel=true lvs_ipv6_addrlabel_value=${ipv6_addrlabel}"

commit_message:
Move container startup to ansible via paunch

This moves from the heat docker-cmd hook, to the paunch utility
which accepts the same json format so we can switch easily.

It seems this doesn't yet correctly handle updates (we get duplicate
containers started), but it enables an end-to-end deployment of each
step via ansible vs multiple SoftwareDeployments per step.

Change-Id: I218d1790e08a72c27e18a9f254403917bc162bc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/85/460285/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Write per-step docker-container-startup-configs copy: content="{{item.value|to_json}}" dest="/var/lib/tripleo-config/docker-container-startup-config-{{item.key}}.json" force=yes with_dict: "{{docker_startup_configs}}" - name: Install paunch FIXME remove when packaged shell: | if [ ! -d /root/paunch ]; then git clone https://github.com/hardys/paunch.git /root/paunch else cd /root/paunch git pull fi yum -y install epel-release yum -y install python-pip yum erase epel-release cd /root/paunch/ pip install . when: step == "1" ################################################## # Per step starting of the containers using paunch ################################################## - name: Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/docker-container-startup-config-step_{{step}}.json exists stat: path: /var/lib/tripleo-config/docker-container-startup-config-step_{{step}}.json register: docker_config_json - name: Start containers for step {{step}} command: paunch apply --file /var/lib/tripleo-config/docker-container-startup-config-step_{{step}}.json --config-id tripleo_step{{step}} --managed-by tripleo when: docker_config_json.stat.exists
deleted_lines: - {{dep.name}}ContainersDeployment_Step{{step}} - name: Write docker-container-startup-configs copy: content="{{docker_startup_configs | to_json}}" dest=/var/lib/docker-container-startup-configs.json force=yes - {{dep.name}}ContainersDeployment_Step{{step -1}} # BEGIN CONTAINER CONFIG STEPS {% for step in range(1, deploy_steps_max) %} {{role.name}}ContainersConfig_Step{{step}}: type: OS::Heat::StructuredConfig properties: group: docker-cmd config: {get_attr: [{{role.name}}DockerConfig, value, step_{{step}}]} {{role.name}}ContainersDeployment_Step{{step}}: type: OS::Heat::StructuredDeploymentGroup depends_on: {%- for dep in roles %} - {{role.name}}PreConfig - {{dep.name}}Deployment_Step{{step}} # baremetal steps of the same level run first {%- if step > 1 %} - {{dep.name}}ContainersDeployment_Step{{step -1}} - {{dep.name}}Deployment_Step{{step -1}} - {{primary_role_name}}DockerPuppetTasksDeployment{{step -1}} {%- endif -%} {%- endfor %} properties: name: {{role.name}}ContainersDeployment_Step{{step}} servers: {get_param: [servers, {{role.name}}]} config: {get_resource: {{role.name}}ContainersConfig_Step{{step}}} {% endfor %} # END CONTAINER CONFIG STEPS

commit_message:
Run puppet host configuration steps via ansible

This writes the puppet step_config manifest to the host and then
runs it for every step, same as we do via heat but via the ansible
playbook.

This also means we need to make the host-prep tasks conditional on
the first step, but it saves the overhead of running a separate
deployment for host prep and the first configuration step.

Change-Id: I41236fde05346fd79d70bb560b502dc731d9cf93

commit_message:
Move create-config-dir steps to HostPrepConfig ansible tasks

This script can be handled via the HostPrepConfig tasks, and it
makes the ordering explicit (as we need the dirs to exist before
we start writing files there)

Change-Id: I43aac414c91774a41137cdbb2f5b504517f975b8

commit_message:
Combine writing docker-puppet json with host_prep_tasks

We've got several host configuration tasks which could be appended to
the host_prep_tasks to reduce the number of discrete deployments
and align with an ansible-based interface.

Change-Id: I391e0262e7cf3d9ca64241c78e602181198fbd00
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/07/456307/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: config: str_replace: template: _PLAYBOOK params: _PLAYBOOK: - hosts: localhost connection: local vars: puppet_config: {get_param: [role_data, {{role.name}}, puppet_config]} tasks: # Join host_prep_tasks with the other per-host configuration yaql: expression: $.data.host_prep_tasks + $.data.template_tasks data: host_prep_tasks: {get_param: [role_data, {{role.name}}, host_prep_tasks]} template_tasks: {%- raw %} # this creates a JSON config file for our docker-puppet.py script - name: Write docker-puppet-tasks json files copy: content="{{puppet_config | to_json}}" dest=/var/lib/docker-puppet/docker-puppet.json force=yes {%- endraw %} depends_on: [{{role.name}}ArtifactsDeploy, {{role.name}}CreateConfigDirDeployment, {{role.name}}HostPrepDeployment]

commit_message:
Convert DockerPuppetTasks to run via ansible

Move the running of docker-puppet into the same playbook that deploys
the json files, this way we can save another SoftwareDeployment
by simply writing the files (and the script) on step 1, then running
it afterwards (by virtue of the playbook task ordering).

Note we deploy the docker-puppet.py script via a text blob in ansible
vars, but this seems somewhat unclean and I'd prefer to move it to
a packaged location eventually, hence leaving a FIXME about it.

Change-Id: Ie1749e984139325f81ac99a062a61a1e5e8d6eab

commit_message:
Format changes only.  No content updates

Removed whitespaces, kept lines under 80, other minor changes

Change-Id: Ib013605b7749f50c84f0d1bbfeb8b471246a6fab
Signed-off-by: Jonathan Almaleh <jonathan.almaleh@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/17/461817/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This section will focus on troubleshooting general "host to host" communication required for the OpenStack control plane to function properly. This does not cover any networking related to instance connectivity. This is assuming a OSA install using LXC containers, VXLAN overlay and the Linuxbridge ml2 driver.1. ``HOST_NET`` (Physical Host Management and Access to Internet) 2. ``CONTAINER_NET`` (LXC container network used for OpenStack Services) 3. ``OVERLAY_NET`` (VXLAN overlay network)**IP address should be applied to physical interface, bond interface, tagged sub-interface, or in some cases the bridge interface (Ex H-1)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 14: bond0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,MASTER,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500...state UP... ...**- br-mgmt should contain veth-pair ends from all containers and a physical interface or tagged-subinterface (Ex C-3)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 18: br-mgmt: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500...state UP... 59: eth1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 ...state UP...**- IP address should be applied to eth10 inside the required LXC containers (Ex O-2)** **- br-vxlan should contain veth-pair ends from required LXC containers and a physical interface or tagged-subinterface (Ex O-3)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 21: br-vxlan: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500...state UP... 67: eth10: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500...state UP...This section will focus on troubleshooting general "instance (VM) connectivity" communication. This does not cover any networking related to instance connectivity. This is assuming a OSA install using LXC containers, VXLAN overlay and the Linuxbridge ml2 driver.- Is the connectivity issue ingress to the instance? - Is the connectivity issue egress from the instance?- If there is a Neutron router in play, on which network node (container) is it hosted?**Does physical interface show link and all VLANs properly trunked across physical network?** - Check cable, seating, physical switchport configuration, interface/bonding configuration and general network configuration. See general network troubleshooting documentation. y. *Do not continue until you verify that physical network is properly configured* **Does the instance's IP address ping from network's DHCP namespace or other instances in the same network?** n. - Check nova console logs to see if the instance ever received its IP address initially - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on the compute and network node - Good! This suggests that the instance received its IP address and can reach local network resources*Do not continue until you verify instance has an IP address and can reach local network resources like DHCP* **Does the instance's IP address ping from the gateway device (Neutron router namespace or another gateway device)?** - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Good! The instance can ping its intended gateway. The issue may be "north" of the gateway or related to the Provider network. - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding ICMP rule for testing - Check Neutron Router Gateway external gateway information (if applicable)**Does physical interface show link and all VLANs properly trunked across physical network?** - Check cable, seating, physical switchport configuration, interface/bonding configuration and general network configuration. See general network troubleshooting documentation. n. - Check br-vxlan interface on Compute and eth10 inside Neutron Network Agent container - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check ml2 config file for local VXLAN IP and other VXLAN configuration settings - If multicast, make sure the physical switches are properly allowing and distributing multicast traffic *Do not continue until you verify that VXLAN endpoints have reachability to each other* **Does the instance's IP address ping from network's DHCP namespace or other instances in the same network?** n. - Check nova console logs to see if the instance ever received its IP address initially - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check that Bridge Forwarding Database (fdb) contains the proper entries on both the compute and Neutron Agent Container - Good! This suggests that the instance received its IP address and can reach local network resources *Do not continue until you verify instance has an IP address and can reach local network resources* **Does the instance's IP address ping from the gateway device (Neutron router namespace or another gateway device)?** - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that Bridge Forwarding Database (fdb) contains the proper entries on both the compute and Neutron Agent Container - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding ICMP rule for testing - Check Neutron Router Gateway external gateway information (if applicable)
deleted_lines: This section will focus on troubleshooting general "host to host" communication required for the Openstack control plane to function properly. This does not cover any networking related to instance connectivity. This is assuming a OSA install using LXC containers, VXLAN overlay and the Linuxbridge ml2 driver.1. HOST_NET (Physical Host Management and Access to Internet) 2. CONTAINER_NET (LXC container network used for communication of Openstack Services) 3. OVERLAY_NET (VXLAN overlay network)**IP address should be applied to physical interface, bond interface, tagged sub-interface, or in some cases the bridge interface (Ex H-1)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 14: bond0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,MASTER,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default ... **- br-mgmt should contain veth-pair ends from all containers and a physical interface or tagged-subinterface (Ex C-3)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 18: br-mgmt: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default 59: eth1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc pfifo_fast state UP group default qlen 1000**- IP address should be applied to eth10 inside the required LXC containers (Ex O-2)** **- br-vxlan should contain veth-pair ends from required LXC containers and a physical interface or tagged-subinterface (Ex O-3)**- Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to edge ports on physical switch - Check VLAN configurations and any necessary trunking to uplink ports on physical switches (if applicable) - Check that hosts are in the same IP subnet or have proper routing between them 21: br-vxlan: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc noqueue state UP group default 67: eth10: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc pfifo_fast state UP group default qlen 1000This section will focus on troubleshooting general "instance (VM) connectivity" communication. This does not cover any networking related to instance connectivity. This is assuming a OSA install using LXC containers, VXLAN overlay and the Linuxbridge ml2 driver.- Is the connectivity issue ingress to the instance or egress from the instance?- If there is a Neutron router in play, on which network node (container) is it hosted?**Does physical interface show link and all VLANs properly trunked across physical network?** - Check cable, seating, physical switchport configuration, interface/bonding configuration and general network configuration. See general network troubleshooting documentation. y. *Do not continue until you verify that physical network is properly configured* **Does the instance's IP address ping from network's DHCP namespace or other instances in the same network?** n. - Check nova console logs to see if the instance ever received its IP address initially - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Good! This suggests that the instance received its IP address and can reach local network resources*Do not continue until you verify instance has an IP address and can reach local network resources like DHCP* **Does the instance's IP address ping from the gateway device (Neutron router namespace or another gateway device)?** - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Good! The instance can ping its intended gateway. The issue may be "north" of the gateway or related to the Provider network. - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding ICMP rule for testing - Check Neutron Router Gateway external gateway information (if applicable)**Does physical interface show link and all VLANs properly trunked across physical network?** - Check cable, seating, physical switchport configuration, interface/bonding configuration and general network configuration. See general network troubleshooting documentation. n. - Check br-vxlan interface on Compute and eth10 inside Neutron Network Agent container - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check ml2 config file for local VXLAN IP and other VXLAN configuration settings - If multicast, make sure the physical switches are properly allowing and distributing multicast traffic *Do not continue until you verify that VXLAN endpoints have reachability to each other* **Does the instance's IP address ping from network's DHCP namespace or other instances in the same network?** n. - Check nova console logs to see if the instance ever received its IP address initially - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check that Bridge Forwarding Database (fdb) contains the proper entries on both the compute and Neutron Agent Container - Good! This suggests that the instance received its IP address and can reach local network resources *Do not continue until you verify instance has an IP address and can reach local network resources* **Does the instance's IP address ping from the gateway device (Neutron router namespace or another gateway device)?** - Check that linuxbridges contain the proper interfaces on compute and network node - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding allow ICMP rule for testing - Check that Bridge Forwarding Database (fdb) contains the proper entries on both the compute and Neutron Agent Container - Check Neutron security-group-rules, consider adding ICMP rule for testing - Check Neutron Router Gateway external gateway information (if applicable)

commit_message:
Handle error response for webob>=1.6.0

WebOb change https://github.com/Pylons/webob/pull/230 changed
the way in which the error response body is formatted such that
it's no longer a nested dict. So we have to handle both the
old convention of an error message key to the response body error
dict and the new way with just the error body dict.

This was reported upstream:

https://github.com/Pylons/webob/issues/235

But given this was apparently implemented as a long-overdue change
in WebOb the behavior is not likely to change.Handle error response for
webob>=1.6.0

Change-Id: I7d589415aa024588faf77c8234ac026110f6c3cd
Closes-Bug: #1559072

commit_message:
Move network admin test classes under admin path

The moved test classes inherit from an admin test class, and it
would be nice to exist under admin path like the other test classes.

NOTE: These test classes are not used from the other projects which
      include Defcore. It is not necessary to take care of this move.

Change-Id: Ie1ba523dbe1ea88ce27a16d9975192d5ce752075

Create a new port post_body = {"network_id": self.network['id']} body = self.admin_ports_client.create_port(**post_body) port = body['port'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_ports_client.delete_port, port['id']) # Update the port's binding attributes so that is now 'bound' # to a host update_body = {"binding:host_id": self.host_id} self.admin_ports_client.update_port(port['id'], **update_body) # List all ports, ensure new port is part of list and its binding # attributes are set and accurate body = self.admin_ports_client.list_ports() ports_list = body['ports'] pids_list = [p['id'] for p in ports_list] self.assertIn(port['id'], pids_list) listed_port = [p for p in ports_list if p['id'] == port['id']] self.assertEqual(1, len(listed_port), 'Multiple ports listed with id %s in ports listing: ' '%s' % (port['id'], ports_list)) self.assertEqual(self.host_id, listed_port[0]['binding:host_id']) @decorators.idempotent_id('b54ac0ff-35fc-4c79-9ca3-c7dbd4ea4f13') def test_show_port_binding_ext_attr(self): body = self.admin_ports_client.create_port( network_id=self.network['id']) port = body['port'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_ports_client.delete_port, port['id']) body = self.admin_ports_client.show_port(port['id']) show_port = body['port'] self.assertEqual(port['binding:host_id'], show_port['binding:host_id']) self.assertEqual(port['binding:vif_type'], show_port['binding:vif_type']) self.assertEqual(port['binding:vif_details'], show_port['binding:vif_details']) class PortsAdminExtendedAttrsIpV6TestJSON(PortsAdminExtendedAttrsTestJSON): _ip_version = 6

commit_message:
Add pbr-installed wsgi application for metadata api

Modify the wsgi application for the compute api so that it can be
used by different services and use it for the metadata service,
resulting in a wsgi script named nova-metadata-wsgi.

Change-Id: Icb35fe2b94ab02c0ba8ba8129ae18aae0f794756
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/13/459413/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: nova-metadata-api = nova.api.metadata.wsgi:init_application

commit_message:
Use plain routes list for server-metadata endpoint instead of stevedore

This patch adds server-metadata related routes by a plain list,
instead of using stevedore. After all the Nova API endpoints moves to the
plain routes list, the usage of stevedore for API loading will be removed
from Nova.

Partial-implement-blueprint api-no-more-extensions-pike

Change-Id: I88ca06d63016ffd1e38b61e6de0b75f88ecdb138

commit_message:
Fix loading 'block_device_mapping' info error

In commit with change-id Ic20b6da85e2cdd9414627e31b0e11276443b8579,
it miss the 'none value judgement', this will cause nova engine
error. This patch will fix it.

Change-Id: I8d3952ea97f554f77856ac9ba89aca8f359afbb0
Closes-Bug: #1687921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/49/462149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: image_block_mapping = json.loads(image_block_mapping_info) \ if image_block_mapping_info else None

commit_message:
Add initial gate for OpenStack-Helm

This patch set is setting up initial lint gate job for the
OpenStack-Helm project.

Co-Authored-By: Alexis Rivera <gardlt@tetrasol.org>

Change-Id: I6ebf2d22467f1c56f474c437abd94e5cc4055ee1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/09/461609/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: TASK :=buildhelm-toolkit: $(TASK)-helm-toolkitceph: $(TASK)-ceph bootstrap: $(TASK)-bootstrap mariadb: $(TASK)-mariadb etcd: $(TASK)-etcd keystone: $(TASK)-keystone cinder: $(TASK)-cinder horizon: $(TASK)-horizon rabbitmq: $(TASK)-rabbitmq glance: $(TASK)-glance mistral: $(TASK)-mistral neutron: $(TASK)-neutron nova: $(TASK)-nova heat: $(TASK)-heat memcached: $(TASK)-memcached ingress: $(TASK)-ingress lint-%: @echo helm lint $* @echo
deleted_lines: helm-toolkit: build-helm-toolkitceph: build-ceph bootstrap: build-bootstrap mariadb: build-mariadb etcd: build-etcd keystone: build-keystone cinder: build-cinder horizon: build-horizon rabbitmq: build-rabbitmq glance: build-glance mistral: build-mistral neutron: build-neutron nova: build-nova heat: build-heat memcached: build-memcached ingress: build-ingress

commit_message:
Add openstack-zuul-jobs / openstack-zuul-roles to zuul.yaml

Add our new projects to then zuulv3-dev.o.o check pipeline.

Change-Id: I40da84853362ce42b1087903a0eabfc681e489d4
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Support configuring inspector processing hooks

As an operator I want to be able to configure the introspection data
processing hooks enabled in ironic inspector so that I can customise the
inspection processing pipeline.

This change allows the set of processing hooks used by inspector to be
configured.

Change-Id: I8e9ec6c78acf5c2b5f8b012bf7d0c41662c5c00f
Closes-Bug: #1685877
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/bifrost refs/changes/04/460004/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: inspector_processing_hooks: String value containing a comma-separated list, default undefined. Use this to specify a non-default list of comma-separated processing hooks for inspector.

Keystone in default devstack installation runs as a uwsgi process
which isn't using ports 5000 and 35357. Instead it uses aliases bind
to default http port.
Set up keystone installation to runs as wsgi which uses default ports
that are used by monasca components.
Change tempest tests configuration to work with
keystone deployed in uwsgi mode.
Remove custom tempest.conf file. Using configure_auth_token_middleware
for monasca-api configuration file and use openrc to generate
environmental variables.

commit_message:
Mofidy tempest tests and WSGI_MODE for keystone

Keystone in default devstack installation runs as a uwsgi process
which isn't using ports 5000 and 35357. Instead it uses aliases bind
to default http port.
Set up keystone installation to runs as wsgi which uses default ports
that are used by monasca components.
Change tempest tests configuration to work with
keystone deployed in uwsgi mode.
Remove custom tempest.conf file. Using configure_auth_token_middleware
for monasca-api configuration file and use openrc to generate
environmental variables.

Story: 2000995
Task: 4173

Change-Id: I337609a471a8ee8e350e149df9e9d7924a730f57

commit_message:
Use package module to install distro packages

Consolidate distro package install tasks into a
single task using the package module.

The minimum Ansible version is raised to 2.2 due to a
known bug [1] in Ansible's apt module which does not
update the cache properly if the cache update and the
install are combined in a single task.

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible-modules-core/issues/1497

Change-Id: I8f4ed2a836b118080bf4698786caab7847f6e799

commit_message:
Add pip_install to repo_server meta-deps

The pip_install role is not technically required for this
role as it does not install any pip packages, however the
pip_install role also sets up EPEL on CentOS and this role
installs packages from EPEL on CentOS.

Depends-On: Ia56d7344572a0addfd4fd5c93832dc66f630e93d
Change-Id: I022669022f4acd797d3d0ab83a714903f5a8aeac

commit_message:
Internal TLS: Use specific CA file for haproxy

Instead of using the CA bundle, this sets HAProxy to use a specific file
for validating the certificates of the services it's proxying. This
helps in two ways:

* Improves performance since validation will check only one certificate.
* Improves security since we're only the certificates signed by one CA
  are valid, instead of any certificate that the system trusts (which
  could include potentially compromised public certs).

Change-Id: Id6de045b3c93c82d37e0b0657c17a3108516016a

commit_message:
Use Sphinx 1.5 warning-is-error

With pbr 2.0 and Sphinx 1.5, the setting for treat sphinx warnings as
errors is setting warning-is-error in build_sphinx section. Enable this.

Change-Id: I981b05275e1a75e3c42ea3ef24812cded0cefc0d

added_lines: all-files = 1 warning-is-error = 1

commit_message:
Explicitly set 'builders' option

An upcoming release of pbr will require explicitly stating which
builders are requested, rather than defaulting to html and man. Head off
any potential impact this may cause by explicitly setting this
configuration now.

Change-Id: I06850630c9e85811a09f8464060728679c093dbf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/66/457966/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: builders = html,man

commit_message:
Use constraints environment for testing

Most projects use upper-constraints.txt from requirements repo
for testing so that we can avoid accidental test breakage.

tools/tox_install.sh does the magic, especially specifying
to use openstacksdk from the current directory. It is required
for library projects.

Change-Id: I7c3f9bcc9f6d911e769e56d9c4cdc74c04a272fc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/25/461225/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install_command = {toxinidir}/tools/tox_install.sh {env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt} {opts} {packages}

commit_message:
Add sudo command for non-root account to mount osd

Generally we specify the user is root when deploying ceph, it is no
problem. But if we have the need to use a non-root account, the deployment
will fail because the non-root account can't use the mount command.
I think it is necessary to add sudo for non-root account, when we can't use
the root account to deploy ceph because of security needs, we can use
non-root account to deploy ceph.

Change-Id: Iea1f30bcf8edbe15dc65909bbae780b55a669067
Closes-Bug: #1668823

added_lines: sudo: yes

useless. On top of that, in my environment the task above has no
"result" key even when successful, so this task then executes and fails.
In other words, we have a debug task which outputs no actual debug
information causing an otherwise successful deploy to fail.

Change-Id: Ie139a9dab82aeb8cadb28b62169640437aaf3e1e
'}]
commit_message:
Remove no_log debug task

This task is there to debug a failed deployment, but because it would
output passwords we added the no_log attribute. That makes it pretty
useless. On top of that, in my environment the task above has no
"result" key even when successful, so this task then executes and fails.
In other words, we have a debug task which outputs no actual debug
information causing an otherwise successful deploy to fail.

Change-Id: Ie139a9dab82aeb8cadb28b62169640437aaf3e1e

commit_message:
Clone zuul from git.openstack.org for zuul-env

Break the dependency on openstack-repos as we are considering removing
this element for zuulv3.  Also, this is a requirement if for us maybe
building our project-config nodepool images in the gate.

Change-Id: I3bddca68385dc6c765fefb01e3042a48c4df5b3d
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add quota options for lbaasv2 configuration

Some quota configuration were missing for lbaasv2.
new vars:
 - neutron_quota_loadbalancer
 - neutron_quota_listener
 - neutron_quota_healthmonitor

Change-Id: Icb65649a613fcb13ae832a0146dd5865e178b9cf

commit_message:
Remove un-used Keystone test path

This patch removes very old and unused Keystone test path, we do
this indirectly by our simple sanity tests (and hopefully) by using
Tempest.

Change-Id: I55916d08942df97990515c76914b799d1f327565

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as ksclient import logging logging.basicConfig(level=logging.WARNING) LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class OpenStackClients(object): def __init__(self): self._connected_clients = {} self._supported_clients = self.__class__.__subclasses__() self.client = None def get_client(self, name): if name in self._connected_clients: return self._connected_clients[name] try: aclass = next(s for s in self._supported_clients if name in s.__name__) sclient = aclass() connected_client = sclient.create() self._connected_clients[name] = connected_client return connected_client except StopIteration: LOG.warning("Requested client %s not found", name) raise def create(self): pass class KeystoneClient(OpenStackClients): def __init__(self): super(KeystoneClient, self).__init__() # TODO(Jeff Peeler): this shouldn't be hard coded self.creds = {'auth_url': 'http://10.0.0.4:5000/v2.0', 'username': 'admin', 'password': 'steakfordinner', 'tenant_name': 'admin'} def create(self): if self.client is None: self.client = ksclient.Client(**self.creds) return self.client if __name__ == '__main__': # TODO(Jeff Peeler): mox this client_mgr = OpenStackClients() ks = client_mgr.get_client('KeystoneClient') LOG.info(ks) ks2 = client_mgr.get_client('KeystoneClient') LOG.info(ks2)

commit_message:
Add documentation for hieradata overrides for the undercloud

Change-Id: Ied84b4bfe8ecc40dd47816dda91e70517744be44
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/04/461804/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Undercloud deployment methods ----------------------------- By default, the undercloud uses the file coming from the hieradata_override_file_classic_undercloud variable to set the hieradata overrides that will be used for the puppet deployment. However, there exists another method for setting up the undercloud based on containers. This method can be used by setting the "containerized_undercloud" variable to 'true' and it's currently experimental. Instead of using the "classic" way to set up hieradata, it uses the file coming from the "hieradata_override_file_t_h_t_undercloud" variable. As the name hints, this deployment method is based on tripleo-heat-templates, and thus, the way of overriding hieradata for it is similar as we do for the overcloud.

commit_message:
Ignore '_comment' as a invalid field in instackenv.json

One way of commenting a json file is to add an '_comment' field.
This will remove any '_comment' field before the node json is checked
for validity.

Change-Id: I67a649edf968a7ead4f38602714506454ca42d67
Closes-Bug: #1685284

subject: Move the gathering of flavors into the CollectFlavors action
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-25 14:05:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/89af281ba0c4fece65add29a3c2cf748425c4359', 'message': 'Move the gathering of flavors into the CollectFlavors action

The imported actions from Mistral (namely, the nova.flavors_list)
will return dictionaries. The nova api returns a Flavor, which has
additional methods (get_keys) that have further properties that are
not returned in the main api call. This works around that.

commit_message:
Move the gathering of flavors into the CollectFlavors action

The imported actions from Mistral (namely, the nova.flavors_list)
will return dictionaries. The nova api returns a Flavor, which has
additional methods (get_keys) that have further properties that are
not returned in the main api call. This works around that.

Change-Id: I3ac99bc5abbae62bfc4352db708e25f5fa551095
Closes-Bug: #1685177

commit_message:
Fix the reporting from the pre-deployment checks workflows

Just using on-complete doesn't seem to do what I expect it to. If there
is an expected error, it will still mark the entire workflow as FAILED.
But using on-success/on-error to the same task does not do so.

Change-Id: Id7b75f22e5adc19cb5c1cce3188a83f38f0b38fd

Touch /etc/httpd/conf.d/ssl.conf

To ensure that yum update passes without issues we touch ssl.conf.
Proper fix is https://review.openstack.org/#/c/456712/

commit_message:
Ensure we configure ssl.conf

Every time we call apache module regardless of using SSL we have to
configure mod_ssl from puppet-apache or we'll hit issue during package
update. File /etc/httpd/conf.d/ssl.conf from mod_ssl package contains
Listen 443 while apache::mod::ssl just configures SSL bits but does not
add Listen. If the apache::mod::ssl is not included the ssl.conf file is
removed and recreated during mod_ssl package update. This causes
conflict on port 443.

Change-Id: Ic5a0719f67d3795a9edca25284d1cf6f088073e8
Related-Bug: 1682448
Resolves: rhbz#1441977
Depends-On: I49bd6f0017048fbab8a4011d5d7c3ffc6cda85b6
(cherry picked from commit 9e729c0db22865d036860346eb6b81c4c2108719)

jobs and services.

commit_message:
Use upper-constraints.txt from stable/kilo

The patch introduces a change in the way we install packages with
tox, ensuring that we use aligned upper constraints from stable/kilo.
Also, tests are fixed.

Fixes for py26 tests are cherry-picked from
2123640a11db81588086f6df1cf343a81c4800f2

flake8 forced to ignore new checks that appeared since the old release

Closes-Bug: #1664619

Change-Id: I6b01c03c20bc2488e76b60f047a0330550febaf5

commit_message:
Add attachment API doc

Add attachment API related Docs, please note we
use 'instance_uuid' in the request and 'instance' in
the response to represent the same thing 'server_id'.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I8bd5a9061af2b47fd227e8cf2f48f80f271bde14

added_lines: _introspect: description: > An internal workflow. The tripleo.baremetal.v1.introspect workflow should be used for introspection. input: - node_uuid output: result: <% $.result %> tasks: start_introspection: action: baremetal_introspection.introspect uuid=<% $.node_uuid %> on-success: passed_introspection on-error: failed_introspection publish: result: <% task().result %> passed_introspection: publish: status: ERROR message: <% task(start_introspection).result %> on-complete: send_message failed_introspection: publish: status: SUCCESS message: <% task(start_introspection).result %> on-complete: send_message send_message: action: zaqar.queue_post retry: count=5 delay=1 input: queue_name: <% $.queue_name %> messages: body: type: tripleo.baremetal.v1._introspect payload: status: <% $.get('status', 'SUCCESS') %> message: <% $.get('message', '') %> execution: <% execution() %> on-success: - fail: <% $.get('status') = "FAILED" %> workflow: _introspect input: node_uuid: <% $.node_uuid %>

commit_message:
Do not log live migration success when it actually failed

During post live migration, if post live migration on destination
fails, then we log a stacktrace but continue to perform cleanup
on the source side. However, at the end of the _post_live_migration
method it was logging that things were successful on the destination
host, which they weren't, which is really confusing when you're trying
to debug the failure and seeing this conflict in the logs.

This patch simply sets a flag if we failed post live migration at
the destination host so we don't log the success message later on
the source host, plus tests to show the flag is set and checked.

Change-Id: I16e70912a13c963031397e66a8553b2c199d50bd
Closes-Bug: #1685340

commit_message:
Remove cache-bindep element

Currently, we only install bindep into a virtualenv in our
cache-bindep element. We can move this into infra-package-needs as an
optimization and reduce elements we depend on.

Change-Id: I591ed9a0835609c1ff8cc6069e45231032fd9f28
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Apache packages to zaqar container

Some projects that use Kolla docker containers (TripleO) run zaqar
under httpd. This patch adds the httpd package so that it exists in the
container and can optionally by used via Docker entrypoints.

As many of these projects do not require the use of Apache (it is
opt-in) at this point not all deployment frameworks support the use of
it so the existing configuration defaults have been left as-is for now.

Change-Id: I35cfd1c2320eb972890b44668c8f9f0a047a65dc
Partially-Implements: blueprint apache-packages-for-apis
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/79/461779/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Create openstack-zuul-jobs / openstack-zuul-roles projects

As we continue with zuulv3, we are ready to start our first steps
towards writing jobs in ansible. As a result, we need a new
untrusted-project for zuul, which will allow dynamic reconfiguration
of jobs. We do not want to use project-config, as it is consider a
config-project and does not support dynamic reconfiguration.

Change-Id: I8732eba9303dc0748723f919d25d8c5dda3a05ed
Needed-By: Ie277f43a4032da24cccf008e8e3e66cc4c678a08
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix Grafana config file template to use variables

Grafana session/provider_config property actually uses a static user
and a static database name.
If grafana_database_user and grafana_database_name default value is
changed, the config generated will not be updated accordingly.

Change-Id: I517daab5439ab1aef56a4b3a11104bd0717223bf
Closes-Bug: #1682810

commit_message:
Magnum: add oslo_messaging_notifications config

Magnum can send RPC notifications to Ceilometer as define here:
https://github.com/openstack/ceilometer/blob/master/ceilometer/pipeline/data/event_definitions.yaml#L554

oslo_messaging_notifications section MUST be managed in magnum.conf file.

Change-Id: I6cafa6666bcb1fc15bf08ef049f0044e788eb98b
Closes-Bug: #1677655
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/57/451857/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove connection: local usage

In Ansible 2.3 the local connection plugin overrides
the host vars for the ansible_python_interpreter,
causing tests to use the wrong interpreter and
install python packages into unexpected locations.
This is especially visible when using host
delegation to localhost instead of the targeting
localhost directly.

To ensure that the behaviour remains consistent with
our expectations all local connection usage for
localhost is removed and localhost is targeted as
a remote host.

Change-Id: Ifcccf3c25aa10085b35017b01644354e10eca15a

the network interfaces") added support for configuring the network on
