commit_message:
Documentation on asynchronous job management API

1. What is the problem
Documentation on asynchronous job management API is not provided.
Currently these APIs are under development, you can find it here[1].
In order to accelerate the pace of development, I plan to upload the
documentation.

2. What is the solution to the problem
Add documentation for asynchronous job management API.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution
None.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/446837

Change-Id: Iccaff47f4ed9a817329197fc229b581e23039492
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/52/456652/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Asynchronous Job ================ XJob provides OpenStack multi-region functionality. It receives and processes jobs from the Admin API or Tricircle Central Neutron Plugin and handles them asynchronously. For job management or resource synchronization purpose, asynchronous job management APIs are developed to perform CRUD operations on job which Tricircle lacks of. +------------------+----------------+---------------------------+------------------------+ |**GET** |/jobs/detail | |Retrieve Job List | +------------------+----------------+---------------------------+------------------------+ This fetches all of the jobs in the Tricircle database. Normal Response Code: 200 **Response** A list of all kinks of jobs. From the perspective of job type, it may include the following jobs: configure extra routes, setup bottom router, delete server port, configure security group rules, update network, update subnet and setup shadow ports. From the perspective of job status, it may contain the new jobs, running jobs, failed jobs and successful jobs. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |body | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |project_id |body | string |project_id is the uuid of a project object in | | | | |KeyStone. "Tenant" is an old term for a project in | | | | |Keystone. Starting in API version 3, "project" is the| | | | |preferred term. They are identical in the context. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |status |body | string |job status, including NEW, RUNNING, SUCCESS, FAIL. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |timestamp |body | timestamp |creation time of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response Example** This is an example of response information for GET /jobs/detail. :: { "jobs": [ { "id": "3f4ecf30-0213-4f1f-9cb0-0233bcedb767", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "port_delete", "timestamp": "2017-03-03 11:05:36", "status": "NEW", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } }, { "id": "b01fe514-5211-4758-bbd1-9f32141a7ac2", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "seg_rule_setup", "timestamp": "2017-03-01 17:14:44", "status": "FAIL", "resource": { "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a" } } ] } +------------------+-------------------+-----------------------+-------------------------------+ |**GET** |/jobs | |Retrieve Job(s) with Filter(s) | +------------------+-------------------+-----------------------+-------------------------------+ Retrieve job(s) from the Tricircle database. We can filter them by project ID, job type and job status. This fetches all the job entries by default, but we can apply filter(s) on the returned values to only show the specific kinds of job entries. Accordingly the filtering condition(s) will be added to the tail of the service url separated by question mark. For example, the default service url is GET /jobs, when filtering is applied, the service url becomes GET /jobs?attribute=attribute_value. One or multiple conditions are supported. Normal Response Code: 200 **Response** The job set contains a list of job entries whose attributes are described in the following table. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |body | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |project_id |body | string |project_id is the uuid of a project object in | | | | |KeyStone. "Tenant" is an old term for a project in | | | | |Keystone. Starting in API version 3, "project" is the| | | | |preferred term. They are identical in the context. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |status |body | string |job status, including NEW, RUNNING, SUCCESS, FAIL. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |timestamp |body | timestamp |creation time of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response Example** This is an example of response information for GET /jobs. By default, all the job entries will be returned. :: { "jobs": [ { "id": "3f4ecf30-0213-4f1f-9cb0-0233bcedb767", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "port_delete", "timestamp": "2017-03-03 11:05:36", "status": "NEW", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } }, { "id": "b01fe514-5211-4758-bbd1-9f32141a7ac2", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "seg_rule_setup", "timestamp": "2017-03-01 17:14:44", "status": "FAIL", "resource": { "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a" } } ] } This is an example of response information for GET /job?type=port_delete. When a filter is applied to the list request, only the specific job entries are retrieved. :: { "jobs": [ { "id": "3f4ecf30-0213-4f1f-9cb0-0233bcedb767", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "port_delete", "timestamp": "2017-03-03 11:05:36", "status": "NEW", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } } ] } +------------------+---------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+ |**GET** |/jobs/{id} | |Retrieve a Single Job | +------------------+---------------+---------------+-------------------------------------+ This fetches a single job entry. The entry may be from job table or job log table. Normal Response Code: 200 **Request** +-------------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +=============+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |path | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-------------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response** This returns detailed information of a job. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |body | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |project_id |body | string |project_id is the uuid of a project object in | | | | |KeyStone. "Tenant" is an old term for a project in | | | | |Keystone. Starting in API version 3, "project" is the| | | | |preferred term. They are identical in the context. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |status |body | string |job status, including NEW, RUNNING, SUCCESS, FAIL. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |timestamp |body | timestamp |creation time of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response Example** This is an example of response information for GET /job/{id}. :: { "job": { "id": "3f4ecf30-0213-4f1f-9cb0-0233bcedb767", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "port_delete", "timestamp": "2017-03-03 11:05:36", "status": "NEW", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } } } +------------------+----------------+---------------------------+------------------------+ |**GET** |/jobs/schemas | |Retrieve Jobs' Schemas | +------------------+----------------+---------------------------+------------------------+ Retrieve all jobs' schemas. Normal Response Code: 200 **Response** A list of all jobs' schemas. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response Example** This is an example of response information for GET /jobs/schemas. :: { "schemas": [ { "type": "router", "resource": ["router_id"] }, { "type": "router_setup", "resource": ["pod_id", "router_id", "network_id"] }, { "type": "port_delete", "resource": ["pod_id", "port_id"] }, { "type": "seg_rule_setup", "resource": ["project_id"] }, { "type": "update_network", "resource": ["pod_id", "network_id"] }, { "type": "subnet_update", "resource": ["pod_id", "subnet_id"] }, { "type": "shadow_port_setup", "resource": [pod_id", "network_id"] } ] } +---------------+-------+------------------------------------+--------------------+ |**POST** |/job | |Create a Job | +---------------+-------+------------------------------------+--------------------+ This creates a new job. If target job already exists in the job table and its status is NEW, then this newer job will be picked up by job handler. Normal Response Code: 202 **Request** Some essential attributes of the job are required and described in the following table. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |project_id |body | string |project_id is the uuid of a project object in | | | | |KeyStone. "Tenant" is an old term for a project in | | | | |Keystone. Starting in API version 3, "project" is the| | | | |preferred term. They are identical in the context. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response** This adds a new job entry in job table. +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |body | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |project_id |body | string |project_id is the uuid of a project object in | | | | |KeyStone. "Tenant" is an old term for a project in | | | | |Keystone. Starting in API version 3, "project" is the| | | | |preferred term. They are identical in the context. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |type |body | string |job type, including router, router_setup, | | | | |port_delete, seg_rule_setup, update_network, | | | | |subnet_update, shadow_port_setup. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |status |body | string |job status, including NEW, RUNNING, SUCCESS, FAIL. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |resource |body | string |all kinds of resources that are needed to run the | | | | |job. It may also contain other necessary parameters | | | | |such as pod_id and project_id that are not members of| | | | |resource group. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |timestamp |body | timestamp |creation time of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Request Example** This is an example of request information for POST /jobs. :: { "job": { "type": "port_delete", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } } } **Response Example** This is an example of response information for POST /jobs. :: { "job": { "id": "3f4ecf30-0213-4f1f-9cb0-0233bcedb767", "project_id": "d01246bc5792477d9062a76332b7514a", "type": "port_delete", "timestamp": "2017-03-03 11:05:36", "status": "NEW", "resource": { "pod_id": "0eb59465-5132-4f57-af01-a9e306158b86", "port_id": "8498b903-9e18-4265-8d62-3c12e0ce4314" } } } +------------------+-----------------+------------------------+-------------------------+ |**DELETE** |/jobs/{id} | |Delete a Job | +------------------+-----------------+------------------------+-------------------------+ Delete a failed or duplicated job from the Tricircle database. Normal Response Code: 200 **Request** +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +===========+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |path | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-----------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response** Nothing will be returned for this request if succeeds, otherwise an exception will be thrown. What's more, we can list all jobs to verify whether it is deleted successfully or not. +------------------+---------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------+ |**PUT** |/jobs/{id} | |Redo a Job | +------------------+---------------+-----------------+-----------------------------------+ Redo a halted job brought by the XJob server corruption or network failures. The job handler will redo a failed job with time interval, but this Admin API will redo a job immediately. Normal Response Code: 200 **Request** Only job id is need. We use HTTP PUT method to redo a job. Regularly HTTP PUT method requires a request body, but considering the job redone operation doesn't need more information other than job id, we will issue this request without a request body. +-------------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ |Name |In | Type | Description | +=============+=======+===============+=====================================================+ |id |path | string |id is a uuid attribute of the job. | +-------------+-------+---------------+-----------------------------------------------------+ **Response** Nothing will be returned for this request, but we can monitor its status through the execution state.

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-03-19 12:44:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tricircle/commit/e3200b526525bddd731275b836fc1d2b9614254c', 'message': 'Implement async job management API

Implement asynchronous job Admin API

1. What is the problem
When XJob receives a job message from service, it will register
the job in database and handle it asynchronously. Tricircle
need to provide API for admin to query the job status and trigger
failed job if something happens unexpectedly. The detailed work
for XJob Admin API is covered in the document[1].

2. What is the solution for the problem
We implement XJob management APIs, they are listed as following:
 *(1) create a job
 *(2) list the jobs
 *(3) delete a job
 *(4) redo a job

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution
After the Admin APIs are implemented, admin can create and
delete an asynchronous job.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/438304/

Change-Id: Ibd90e539c9360a0ad7a01eeef185c0dbbee9bb4e

commit_message:
Implement asynchronous job Admin API

1. What is the problem
When XJob receives a job message from service, it will register
the job in database and handle it asynchronously. Tricircle
needs to provide API for admin to query the job status and trigger
failed job if something happens unexpectedly. The detailed work
for XJob Admin APIs is covered in the document[1].

2. What is the solution for the problem
We implement XJob management APIs, they are listed as following:
 *(1) create a job
 *(2) list single job info
 *(3) list all jobs
 *(4) list jobs with filters
 *(5) list all jobs' schemas
 *(6) delete a job
 *(7) redo a job

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution
Implement above job operations.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/438304/

Change-Id: Ibd90e539c9360a0ad7a01eeef185c0dbbee9bb4e

commit_message:
WIP Remove Newton to Ocata Upgrades code

DO NOT MERGE - doing this after looking at
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/454759/
For Ocata to Pike we have docker/services providing
the upgrade_tasks. Also removes some older environment
files no longer relevant for current release.

Really though I don't want to land this, yet. We are still landing
fixes for N..O into stable/ocata which is still the current stable
branch. I think we should hold on this until closer to P relase?

Change-Id: Ifba369bf1267f7a9f389d6e7770bcb368eb5c9b3

commit_message:
Using active inspection in huge environments

Change-Id: I5ed64d1c6ead735a87cbfa88c21278e5c77c5eae
Partial-Bug: #1670601
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector-specs refs/changes/21/452121/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Using active inspection in large-scale environments =================================================== https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic-inspector/+bug/1670601 This blueprint is for adding new ironic-inspect feature to support active inspection. Problem description =================== Before baremetal servers can be provisioned by ironic, the ironic service should know the hardware properties for nova scheduling and the link connections between baremetal node and ToR switch for SDN controller. During the procedure of baremetal introspection, we may face a lot of problems, such as hardware problem, network problem and ironic service problem. Deploying a large-scale baremetal server cloud is very time-consuming. As we know, ironic-inspector HA is under developing, and auto-discovery can be used in the automation scenarios. However, in our environment, each baremetal server has individual IMPI credentials, it's hard to use auto-discovery feature. After several experiments, we think ironic-inspector service can perform service advertisement and listen for baremetal server callback simultaneously. Furthermore, this approach is regardless of whether HA feature is enabled or not. Proposed change =============== :: +-------------------------+ +-------------------------+ +-------------------------+ |ironic-inspector server 1| |ironic-inspector server 2| |ironic-inspector server 3| | (dnsmasq) | | (dnsmasq) | | (dnsmasq) | +----------+--------------+ +-----------+-------------+ +------------+------------+ | | | | XXXXXXXXXXX | | | XXXX XX++XX | +----------------+ | XX XXXX | +-------+ tftp server 1 | +----------------+X X+-------------------------+ | +----------------+ XX XX+--------------------------------+ X inspect network X +----------------+ XX +---------------------------------------+ tftp server 2 | XX X +----------------+ XXXX +--------------------------------+ +----------------------+XX X+----------------------+ | +----------------+ | XXXXXX XXX | +--------+ tftp server 3 | | XX++XXXXX | +----------------+ | | | | | | +----------+---------+ +----------+---------+ +----------+---------+ +--------------------+ | baremetal server 1 | | baremetal server 2 | | baremetal server 3 | ... | baremetal server n | +--------------------+ +--------------------+ +--------------------+ +--------------------+ Figure 1. Basic topology As the above figure illustrates, multiple ironic-inspector servers can manage thousands of bare metal servers. In order to achieve active inspection, we need make some necessary changes. The proposed changes include: 1. ironic-inspector configure options * active_mode=[True|False] If enable active mode, ironic-inspector service will add a new period task to send service advertisement message and allow no-cache node to call /v1/continue API. * advertisement_period=15 Amount of time in seconds, after which sending an advertisement message. * group_address=224.0.0.200 IP Destination address, must be multicast address. Administrator shall choose a IANA unassigned address to avoid conflict. * advertisement_port=40000 UDP destination port, uses for ironic-python-agent to listen on this UDP port. * send_interfaces=bond0,bond1 If ``listen_address`` is set and not all-zero, then this option will be ignored. Otherwise, advertisement messages will be sent out to these interfaces. * ipa_secret=0123456789 This option holds the secret string used to validate post /v1/continue requests. If set, ironic-python-agent shall include the same secret string in the post request. 2. ironic-python-agent configure options * inspect_advertisement_group_address=224.0.0.200 The group address to listen on. If set, will override ``inspection_callback_url``. * inspect_advertisement_port=40000 ironic-python-agent listens on this UDP port for receiving advertisement message. 3. /v1/continue API behavior If active_mode set True, then allows no-cache node to call POST /v1/continue API. Creats node cache and process the introspection data properly. 4. /v1/introspection/<node_id> API behavior If active_mode set True, then ignore FSM process and node add process. 5. advertisement message format :: +----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ |Ethernet header| IP header | UDP header | TLV 1 | TLV 2 | ... | TLV n | +----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ The payload is encoded as Type + length + value format. Suggested Types: 0x01: advertisement message, length shall be 2, value is 0x0101 (both ironic-inspector and ironic-python-agent use the same value). 0x02: my IP address, length shall be 4 (IPV4) or 16 (IPV6). 0x03: inspection callback url, no fixed length. 0x04: advertisement message interval, in seconds, length shall be 2, value 0~65535 seconds. 0x05: Status, length shall be 3. Value also sub-TLV. Possible values are: .. 0x01: Active, length shall be 0. .. 0x02: Inactive, length shall be 0. .. 0x03: Overload, length shall be 0. .. 0x04: Leaving, length shall be 0. 0x06: ipa secret, no fixed length. Take an example, ironic-inspector (my IP address 172.10.10.10, group address 224.0.1.240) sends the following advertisement message. Ethernet header: .. Source MAC address: it's own, maybe ``listen_address`` MAC or send_interfaces MAC. .. Destination MAC address: 01:00:5E:00:01:F0 .. Ethernet type: 0x0800 IP header: .. Source IP address: 172.10.10.10 .. Destination IP address: 224.0.1.240 UDP header: .. Source port: random by TCP/IP stack .. Destination port: ``advertise_port`` TLV: .. Type: 0x01, Length: 2, Value: 0x0101. .. Type: 0x02, Length: 4, Value: 172.10.10.10 .. Type: 0x03, Length: 36, Value: 'http://172.10.10.10:5050/v1/continue' .. Type: 0x04, Length: 2, Value: 15 .. Type: 0x05, Length: 3, Value: sub-TLV .. Type: 0x01 (Active), Length: 0, Value: null .. Type: 0x06, Length: 10, Value: '0123456789'. 6. dnsmasq configuration No change is needed. Make sure no IP address overlapps or conflicts if deploys multiple dnsmasq instances in a same layer2 network. Recommend to set individual next-server (tftp server) in each dnsmasq instance to achieve tftp server load-balance. Besides this, managing firewall must be set to avoid dhcp service conflict with neutron-dhcp-agent. 7. introspection process a. Once ironic-inspector service starts, it adds a period task to send advertisement message. As basic topology shows, if all the three ironic-inspector services started, then we could see that they send advertisement messages periodically. b. If administrator decides to perform inspect on one or multiple baremetal servers. First, executing ``openstack baremetal introspection start <node uuid>``, then set ``pxe boot enable`` and reboot. c. Once baremetal server power on, ironic-python-agent starts to run, it collects hardware properties. At the same time, ironic-python-agent listens advertisement message. d. Once receive the advertisement message, baremetal server handles the message. After necessary message examination, takes ``inspection callback url`` as the key, if the url does not exists, then adds a new record to inspect service table, otherwise updates the record. :: +------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | NO | INSPECTION CALLBACK URL | STATUS | INTERVAL | EXPERION TIMER | +------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 1 | http://1.1.1.1:5050/v1/continue | ACTIVE | 15 | 00:00:40 | +------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 2 | http://1.1.1.2:5050/v1/continue | ACTIVE | 15 | 00:00:42 | +------------------------------------------------------------------------------+ | 3 | http://1.1.1.3:5050/v1/continue | OVERLOAD| 15 | 00:00:35 | +------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Table 1. ironic inspect service table As table 1 illustrates, the interval value should be used to check whether the ironic-inspector service is alive. If exceeds three times interval, no more advertisement message received, then treats this service is dead and deletes it. Once ironic-python-agent collects data finished, it needs to choose (via hash method) one active ironic-inspector service to upload the data via POST /v1/continue API. If no active ironic-inspector service exists, it could choose an overload service instead. The ironic-python-agent must wait for the acknowledge message before exit, it should retry multiple times until get the acknowledge message. Once ironic-inspector receives the API request, it processes the data. Once the data processes complete, it will reply with acknowledge message. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- If active mode on, then allows node_cache_not_found node to create node cache in process() method. Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Scalability impact ------------------ Simultaneous introspection will be faster. Performance Impact ------------------ TBD Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittests will be added. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== TBD Documentation Impact ==================== TBD References ========== [1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-inspector-specs/specs/\ HA_inspector.html [2] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ironic-inspector-specs/specs/\ ironic-node-auto-discovery.html

In Bug #1586056 was implemented a method to check the rule type
in a QoS policy when it's assigned to a port. This method checks
the port backend driver support for the list of rules. If any
rule is not supported, the QoS policy is not binded to this port.

The check removed in this patch is not needed anymore.

Closed-Bug: #1686627

Change-Id: I6a6b5c3397c6bbe4f97130d6a54ba2ab610207d9

commit_message:
Remove QoS rule check in agent extension

In Bug #1586056 was implemented a method to check the rule type
in a QoS policy when it's assigned to a port. This method checks
the port backend driver support for the list of rules. If any
rule is not supported, the QoS policy is not binded to this port.

The check removed in this patch is not needed anymore.

Closed-Bug: #1686627
Related-Bug: #1586056

Change-Id: I6a6b5c3397c6bbe4f97130d6a54ba2ab610207d9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/60/460460/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron._i18n import _LI rule_types = set([rule.rule_type for rule in qos_policy.rules]) for rule in qos_policy.rules:
deleted_lines: from neutron._i18n import _LW, _LI rule_types = set( [rule.rule_type for rule in self._iterate_rules(qos_policy.rules)]) def _iterate_rules(self, rules): for rule in rules: rule_type = rule.rule_type if rule_type in self.SUPPORTED_RULES: yield rule else: LOG.warning(_LW('Unsupported QoS rule type for %(rule_id)s: ' '%(rule_type)s; skipping'), {'rule_id': rule.id, 'rule_type': rule_type}) for rule in self._iterate_rules(qos_policy.rules):

subject: [Urgent] mock _update_ips_for_port
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-03 03:36:07.000000000', 'files': ['tricircle/tests/unit/network/test_central_plugin.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tricircle/commit/fc40b6a016ae02d9cdb05cfa2eccb5a57a178e1d', 'message': "[Urgent] mock _update_ips_for_port

1. What is the problem?
After patch[1] merged, update mac address will also trigger ip updating
process. This is mainly for IPv6 address but the code logic doesn't
distinguish ip version. Some methods used by ip updating process are not
correctly simulated in FakeQuery so test_update_port test failed.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Since we don't support ip updating currently, one simple fix is to mock
_update_ips_for_port method.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/46d1a890e700dfa6e921387569f87f793ca4e8e9

Change-Id: I13c1e802248bc1bf46e44a067b018b674ded46a2
"}]
commit_message:
[Urgent] mock _update_ips_for_port

1. What is the problem?
After patch[1] merged, update mac address will also trigger ip updating
process. This is mainly for IPv6 address but the code logic doesn't
distinguish ip version. Some methods used by ip updating process are not
correctly simulated in FakeQuery so test_update_port test failed.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Since we don't support ip updating currently, one simple fix is to mock
_update_ips_for_port method.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/46d1a890e700dfa6e921387569f87f793ca4e8e9

Change-Id: I13c1e802248bc1bf46e44a067b018b674ded46a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/78/461978/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def fake_update_ips_for_port(self, context, port, host, original_ips, new_ips, mac): # NOTE: remove this mock after we support ip updating return ipam_pluggable_backend.IpamPluggableBackend.Changes( add=[], original=[], remove=[]) @patch.object(ipam_pluggable_backend.IpamPluggableBackend, '_update_ips_for_port', new=fake_update_ips_for_port)

commit_message:
Fix py35 test failure

dict.keys() returns object dict_keys on Python 3, can't work well
with kombu recently, convert it to list before futhur processing.

Closes-Bug: #1687855
Change-Id: I9dcfadd8f16eccce06f4cde3b2a6669f28a3f8bc

commit_message:
tempest: ignore 2 unstable tests for Gnocchi

2 tests are timeouting too often and it makes our CI unstable.
Let's ignore the tests now.

Change-Id: I0140e774c0ee27926f03c01a972fb76721e71528

subject: [urgent]Adapt new Keystone URL and mock _update_ips_for_port
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-19 10:52:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tricircle/commit/97f9f5c1e325799c22fb18e9ccd0e31370bec8d8', 'message': "Adapt new Keystone URL

1. What is the problem?
Now Keystone can use uwsgi with proxy[1], and this is the default mode
in DevStack. In this case, the original URL with 5000/35357 port can
no longer be accessed.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Change Keystone public URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:5000/v3 to http://host/identity/v3 and
change Keystone admin URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:35357/v3 to http://host/identity_admin/v3

This patch also fixes a mistake which was hidden before this Keystone
change. While generating Tricircle apache configuration file in our
DevStack script, TRICIRCLE_BIN in the template is not replaced by
the real value. So the directory access right is not correctly granted.
Before this Keystone change, Keystone apache configuration file will
grant right on the same directory, so we didn't notice this problem.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/commit/
    6ed53156b6198e69d59d1cf3a3497e96f5b7a870

Change-Id: I2b43c630eedff0f808c729da0ce9b819f02495dd

After patch[1] merged, update mac address will also trigger ip updating
process. This is mainly for IPv6 address but the code logic doesn't
distinguish ip version. Some methods used by ip updating process are not
correctly simulated in FakeQuery so test_update_port test failed

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Change Keystone public URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:5000/v3 to http://host/identity and
change Keystone admin URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:35357/v3 to http://host/identity

This patch also fixes a mistake which was hidden before this Keystone
change. While generating Tricircle apache configuration file in our
DevStack script, TRICIRCLE_BIN in the template is not replaced by
the real value. So the directory access right is not correctly granted.
Before this Keystone change, Keystone apache configuration file will
grant right on the same directory, so we didn't notice this problem.

Since we don't support ip updating currently, one simple fix is to mock
_update_ips_for_port method.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/commit/
    6ed53156b6198e69d59d1cf3a3497e96f5b7a870

Change-Id: I2b43c630eedff0f808c729da0ce9b819f02495dd

commit_message:
[urgent]Adapt new Keystone URL and mock _update_ips_for_port

1. What is the problem?
Now Keystone uses uwsgi with proxy[1], and this is the default mode
in DevStack. In this case, the original URL with 5000/35357 port can
no longer be accessed, this change will lead to Tricircle gate/check
test always failure if no adaption is made in Tricircle configuration.

After patch[2] merged, update mac address will also trigger ip updating
process. This is mainly for IPv6 address but the code logic doesn't
distinguish ip version. Some methods used by ip updating process are not
correctly simulated in FakeQuery so test_update_port test failed

2. What is the solution to the problem?
Change Keystone public URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:5000/v3 to http://host/identity and
change Keystone admin URL Tricircle uses from
http://host:35357/v3 to http://host/identity

This patch also fixes a mistake which was hidden before this Keystone
change. While generating Tricircle apache configuration file in our
DevStack script, TRICIRCLE_BIN in the template is not replaced by
the real value. So the directory access right is not correctly granted.
Before this Keystone change, Keystone apache configuration file will
grant right on the same directory, so we didn't notice this problem.

Since we don't support ip updating currently, one simple fix is to mock
_update_ips_for_port method.

3. What features need to be implemented to the Tricircle
to realize the solution?
No new features.

[1] https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/commit/
    6ed53156b6198e69d59d1cf3a3497e96f5b7a870
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/
    46d1a890e700dfa6e921387569f87f793ca4e8e9

Change-Id: I2b43c630eedff0f808c729da0ce9b819f02495dd

commit_message:
Use instance snapshot launch instance failed

I am running OpenStack Kilo on CentOS7.1 with VMware vSphere 5.5 Enterprise Plus.
I have created snapshot for the instance. OS of the instance is Windows Server 2008 R2 and VMware tools have been installed. The size of snapshot is 3.2G. When I launch intance using this snapshot, instance failed to spawn.

Change-Id: If3f2f70b901d1b35cd5d283a95afc063d63ff8a2
Closes-Bug: #1584676

commit_message:
Use voluptuous instead of jsonschema (WIP)

The voluptuous is easier to use for non-rest
oriented library & services (which is really
the place for jsonschema to be used, as the
schema for rest-services can be sent to the
user in json if needed) so use voluptuous
internally instead of jsonschema for simplicity
and ease of use.

Change-Id: I9edc87bf347523630507e9e5849981e4a096df68

commit_message:
Add the update-plan-only step for the minor updates workflow

Currently we are missing the step to bring updated tht templates
in the swift container. Without that step you will run a minor update
which will always run the yum_update.sh script that was around
deployment time, making it impossible to ship fixes to the script
itself.

Change-Id: I28696be9925a31d305a4faca10a95ce7c7644cb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/13/461013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Updating packages on all overcloud nodes involves two steps. The first one makes sure that the overcloud plan is updated (a new tripleo-heat-templates rpm might have brought fixes/changes to the templates):: openstack overcloud deploy --update-plan-only \ --templates \ -e <full environment> By using the parameter ``--update-plan-only`` we make sure we update only the stored overcloud plan and not the overcloud itself. Make sure you pass the exact same environment parameters that were used at deployment time. The second step consists in updating the packages themselves on all overcloud nodes with a command similar to the following:: commands.
deleted_lines: You can update packages on all overcloud nodes with a command similar to the following:: commands.

commit_message:
When generating local console scripts, should give user a choice to
decide whether add -O to ‘executable’, such as '/usr/bin/python -O'

Currently, after installing openstack, such as openstack/cinder,
all console scripts under /usr/bin have the top one line like
'#!/usr/bin/python'.

This will result to starting services failure if only .pyo left.

This change updates class of LocalInstallScripts to allow user to
decide whether to add -O option by adding 'Support Pyo :: True' in
setup.cfg.

Change-Id: I47a1bda9314b9cc9a0369472367f38e058d8dd73
Closes-bug: #1619560
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/59/364759/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # if 'Support Pyo :: True' in classifier of setup.cfg, then append # ' -O' to executable. if 'Support Pyo :: True' in self.distribution.get_classifiers(): executable += ' -O'

subject: Making 'pbr' open for extension by 3rd party libs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-24 01:48:52.000000000', 'files': ['pbr/util.py', 'pbr/core.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/pbr/commit/8cd2103ef65d84e29dfa52faba3afbc55517d3d3', 'message': "Making 'pbr' open for extension by 3rd party libs

    The rationale behind this change is that 'pbr' provides a solid amount
    of useful functionality that could be used not only for creating Python
    packages but also for building new tools for automated package creation.

    In fact there are only 2 'entry-points' that should be opened for
    extension in order to make 'pbr' into a framework. It should be stressed
    that this changes are completely backward compatible and will not break
    anything as they do not change the behavior.

    1st change: an optional 'pbr_hook_name' parameter added to 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

        This way the pbr_hook in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args' is configurable
        through the 'pbr_hook_name' parameter. On top of opening this
        function for extension by 3rd party libs we also can use dependency
        injection in for unit-testing purpose by providing fake pbr_hook
        implementation and simplifying prerequisites.

        As a bonus we removed duplication - previously pbr_hook was
        referred 2 times: by its FQN and by direct call.

    2nd change: an optional 'pbr_hook_name' parameter added to 'pbr.core:pbr'

        This change is needed in order to allow 3rd party libs to re-use
        pbr's setup() keyword. Here is an example of intended extension:

        packman.py:
        ```
            from pbr.core import pbr

            def setup_hook(config):
                pass  # Whatever extension

            def setup_kw(dist, attr, value):
                pbr(dist, attr, value, pbr_hook_name='packman.setup_hook')
        ```

        setup.cfg
        ```
            [entry_points]
            distutils.setup_keywords =
                packman = packman:setup_kw
        ```

    On top of 2 changes mentioned above there are 3 small cosmetic changes:

        A. Fixed docstring in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

            Changed docstring parameter name from 'file' (actually there are no
            parameters with such name) to 'path'.

        B. Removed excess space between 'try' and ':' in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

        C. Removed duplicated setup.cfg existence check

            The setup.cfg existence check dropped from 'pbr.core.pbr' since it
            directly preceded the 'pbr.util.cfg_to_args' call, that already has the
            same check implemented at the very beginning

Change-Id: Ib4ad2c458d39a80d3cb3780976f81b661f2a5cae
"}]
commit_message:
Making 'pbr' open for extension by 3rd party libs

    The rationale behind this change is that 'pbr' provides a solid amount
    of useful functionality that could be used not only for creating Python
    packages but also for building new tools for automated package creation.

    In fact there are only 2 'entry-points' that should be opened for
    extension in order to make 'pbr' into a framework. It should be stressed
    that this changes are completely backward compatible and will not break
    anything as they do not change the behavior.

    1st change: an optional 'pbr_hook_name' parameter added to 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

        This way the pbr_hook in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args' is configurable
        through the 'pbr_hook_name' parameter. On top of opening this
        function for extension by 3rd party libs we also can use dependency
        injection in for unit-testing purpose by providing fake pbr_hook
        implementation and simplifying prerequisites.

        As a bonus we removed duplication - previously pbr_hook was
        referred 2 times: by its FQN and by direct call.

    2nd change: an optional 'pbr_hook_name' parameter added to 'pbr.core:pbr'

        This change is needed in order to allow 3rd party libs to re-use
        pbr's setup() keyword. Here is an example of intended extension:

        packman.py:
        ```
            from pbr.core import pbr

            def setup_hook(config):
                pass  # Whatever extension

            def setup_kw(dist, attr, value):
                pbr(dist, attr, value, pbr_hook_name='packman.setup_hook')
        ```

        setup.cfg
        ```
            [entry_points]
            distutils.setup_keywords =
                packman = packman:setup_kw
        ```

    On top of 2 changes mentioned above there are 3 small cosmetic changes:

        A. Fixed docstring in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

            Changed docstring parameter name from 'file' (actually there are no
            parameters with such name) to 'path'.

        B. Removed excess space between 'try' and ':' in 'pbr.util:cfg_to_args'

        C. Removed duplicated setup.cfg existence check

            The setup.cfg existence check dropped from 'pbr.core.pbr' since it
            directly preceded the 'pbr.util.cfg_to_args' call, that already has the
            same check implemented at the very beginning

Change-Id: Ib4ad2c458d39a80d3cb3780976f81b661f2a5cae

commit_message:
Support build metadata

Add support for the build metadata already documented in Semantic
Versioning.  Build metadata consists of a '+' followed by arbitrary
(in this implementation) text at the end of a version string.  For
comparison purposes, all build metadata sorts after the plain
version string, but is otherwise unsorted with respect to other
build metadata.  Equality still requires an exact match.

In retrieving the version tags from a git repository, any tag with
'+' that is not associated with the most recent commit is ignored.
If the current commit contains multiple tags with '+', an error is
raised.

Change-Id: I819e469a4ce4856fc08d181c541844081c07cc28
Closes-Bug: #1452515
